Challenger Page randomly displays a state for each phase or category as well as all of the user response options for that category. Authors are highly encouraged to learn more about Challenger Pages in Help > General LodeStar Help. || Palette: Uses Background chip for background, Medium for Category buttons.

Crossword converts a word list into a crossword that students must solve.||To set up a crossword, enter in a word and a hint, which will be displayed to the students. Click on '+' to add new words. Click on 'Compile' to generate the crossword.|| Palette: Uses Light chip for background.

The Fill-in-the-Blanks Page converts text formatted with a strike-through to fill-in-the-blanks. It also displays text, images, and even MathML and embedded objects from Web 2.0 applications.||Optionally, insert widgets into pages. Widgets allow you to add multiple choice questions, short answer questions and more to the page. Look for the Widget Button (sprocket) on the HTML Editor tool bar. || Palette: Does not use Palette. Uses Theme.

The Flashcard page displays text and an image. Use Short Answer field to provide the right answer. Regular Expressions are supported. When a flashcard is correctly answered, it is removed from the flow.|| Palette: Uses Light chip for background.

This is an advanced page type, which is not recommended without training. To fully learn about a forms page, please consult the FAQ. The forms page creates an interactive form that is connected to long answer pages by id. The title field holds the title that appears on an interactive form. The abbreviation is used when there is no room for the full title. The ID field holds an HTML ID that is used to connect the form to the forms.css (stylesheet) and to a long answer page. Match the long answer page ID to this ID.|| Palette: Uses Light chip for background, Medium for form headings.

A Gate will branch the program flow based on the performance of the student.||Click on the 'Pass' options button to set the branch options for a student who has matched or exceeded the pass score. Click on the 'Fail' button to set the branch options for a student who hasn't succeeded.|| Palette: Gate is never visible to learner.
The IFrame page allows you to paste in an embed code and then properly display the iFrame so that it is adaptive to a variety of screen sizes, including mobile. || Palette: Not used.

The Interview page presents student with information, such as an interview question, that the student must respond to by selecting one of three responses. The responses are judged.||Type in what the character says. Type in three responses that are presented to students as options. Type in a value (in points) that students will receive for each option. The highest value will become the total score for this page.|| Palette: Uses Extra Light for background, Light for answer options.

The Journal page combines and presents all of the student entries from the long answer pages.||Student responses will be automatically collated and presented. || Palette: Uses Light Chip for background.

The Long Answer page presents students with a text area in which to key in a long response (a paragraph, for example).||Long answer responses are reported to the learning management system (SCORM report)and collated on the Journal Page. Students can then copy the Journal Page, paste into a Word document and submit to instructor.||Use the 'Heading' field to organize the responses in the Journal Page. || Palette: Uses Light Chip for background.

The Multiple Choice Page supports a question stem and 1 to 5 options or distractors.||Each distractor can be supplied with feedback text and, optionally, a branching option.||Indicate which answers are correct by checking the 'correct' checkboxes. Enter in a point value.||This page type supports True and False (just use two distractors), multiple choice and multiple select. || Palette: Uses Extra Light for background, Light for Answer Options.

The Multiple Select Page supports a question stem and 1 to 5 options or distractors.||Each distractor can be supplied with feedback text.||Indicate which answers are correct by checking the 'correct' checkboxes. Enter in a point value.||This page type supports True and False (just use two distractors), multiple choice and multiple select.|| Palette: Uses Extra Light for background, Light for Answer Options.

The Organizer Page has many uses. The simplest use is to fill in items that students must order (chronologically, geographically, logically, etc.)||Enter in text. Indicate correct order by filling in a number for position. Ignore the other fields.||Organizer will randomize the items so that students can order them. || Palette: Uses Extra light for background, Light for draggable items.

The Report Page causes information to be sent to the Learning Management System related to the student's performance.||Enter in additional information that you would like students to see. || Palette: Does not use palette. Color controlled by Theme.

The Short Answer Page challenges students to type in a short answer in response to a question.||Enter in the question and the correct answer. You may use a vertical bar to separate options.||If you are familiar with regular expressions, you can check the Reg Ex box and use regular expressions. The template help (Help > Template Help)gives you more information on regular expressions. || Palette: Uses Extra Light for answer field, Light for background.

The Simple Sim page presents student with information, such as an interview question, that the student must respond to by selecting one of three responses. The responses are judged.||Type in a prompt. Type in three responses that are presented to students as options. Type in a value (in points) that students will receive for each option. The highest value will become the total score for this page.|| Palette: Uses Dark chip for panel background.

The Text Page displays text, images, and even MathML and embedded objects from Web 2.0 applications.||Optionally, insert widgets into pages. Widgets allow you to add multiple choice questions, short answer questions and, in the future, other types of widgets to the page. Look for the Widget Button on the HTML Editor tool bar. || Palette: Does not use palette. Page color is controlled by Theme (for all pages) or by HTML Editor Image Tool.

The Video Page supports YouTube videos, MediaSpace, and imported MP4 files.||For YouTube and MediaSpace videos paste in the URL in the first field. (Consult the General Help for MediaSpace directions). Otherwise click the 'Import Video' button. You can also import a captions file.|| Palette: Does not use palette

The Wall Page stops the student from navigating to the next section of content. Students must 'branch' to the other side of the wall from any of the page types that support branching such as the Question Page or Gate.|| Palette: Walls are not visible to learner.

entrydata.input:
Meet Nikolai (Kolya)  

During the start of the 2020 pandemic, Kolya took up a new interest.  


Whenever he has some spare time he logs into his free account on the US National Archives website (NARA) to contribute work on the "'citizen' archivist" project.  

His contributions as part of a volunteer crowd-sourced labor force helps to make digitized archival materials accessible, discoverable and usable by and for the public. 


Since 2020, Kolya has transcribed a variety of archival items ranging from US Revolutionary War Pension Files to JFK Assassination Records.

He recently watched a TEDTalk that made him aware that traditional archival practices often reproduce the marginalization of populations that have historically faced discrimination, oppression and 'symbolic annihilation'.  

One restorative practice that seeks to mitigate such harm, is called "reparative description."


Source: NARA. https://catalog.archives.gov/id/176561681

Meet Nikolai (Kolya)  

During the start of the 2020 pandemic Kolya took up a new interest.  

Whenever he has some spare time he logs into his free account on the US National Archives website (NARA) to contribute work on the "'citizen' archivist" project.  

His contributions as part of a volunteer crowd-sourced labor force helps to make digitized archival materials accessible, discoverable and usable by and for the public. 

Since 2020, Kolya has transcribed a variety of archival items ranging from US Revolutionary War Pension Files to JFK Assassination Records.

He recently watched a TEDTalk that made him aware that traditional archival practices often reproduce the marginalization of populations that have historically faced discrimination, oppression and 'symbolic annihilation'.  

2 images.  1 large and 1 small... of cover page of 1838 treaty between Six Nations and United States government.


Kolya doesn't want to marginalize...

oppress or 'symbolically annhiliate' anyone. Except maybe his neighbor when he plays the tuba at 4 a.m.

He also doesn't want to give up his newfound interest volunteering to transcribe and tag archival material.

source: NARA. https://catalog.archives.gov/id/176561681

Meet Nikolai (Kolya)  

During the start of the 2020 pandemic Kolya took up a new interest.  

Whenever he has some spare time he logs into his free account on the US National Archives website (NARA) to contribute work on the "'citizen' archivist" project.  

His contributions as part of a volunteer crowd-sourced labor force helps to make digitized archival materials accessible, discoverable and usable by and for the public. 

Since 2020, Kolya has transcribed a variety of archival items ranging from US Revolutionary War Pension Files to JFK Assassination Records.

He recently watched a TEDTalk that made him aware that traditional archival practices often reproduce the marginalization of populations that have historically faced discrimination, oppression and 'symbolic annihilation'.  

2 images.  1 large and 1 small... of cover page of 1838 treaty between Six Nations and United States government.


Kolya doesn't want to marginalize...

oppress or 'symbolically annhiliate' anyone. Except maybe his neighbor when he plays the tuba at 4 a.m.

He also doesn't want to give up his newfound interest volunteering to transcribe and tag archival material.

entrydata.input:
Kolya needs some help.  


Your mission is to guide Kolya in using new and emerging best practices for reparative description in his volunteer work as a *'citizen' archivist.


*NARA (US National Archives and Records Administration) refers to the crowd-sourced volunteer project as "'citizen' archivist projects."  

It ought to be recognized that the term 'citizen' carries a heavy and consequential connotation for people with undocumented status.  

Anyone can contribute to the NARA volunteer archiving projects regardless of citizenship status.

entrydata.input:
Appendix: Reparative Description Preferred Terms

Introduction

About the Reparative Description Preferred Terms

The appendix includes reparative description preferred terms to support reparative description efforts of National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) archivists, specialists, technicians, and staff to identify, evaluate, and update potentially harmful and outdated language in our archival descriptions. 

The list of non-preferred and preferred terms for reparative description links to guidance and notes on how to apply the preferred terms for archival description. 

The general guidance and style guide provides guidelines for using the preferred terms within Lifecycle Data Requirements Guide (LCDRG) data elements and access points.

NARAs reparative description and digitization work is happening in the context of similar efforts at many other research libraries, private institutions, and government archives in the U.S. and across the globe. NARA made benchmarking a key component of our research for the non-preferred and preferred terms. We received input and feedback from community stakeholders on our approach to reparative description and on the non-preferred and preferred terms.

source: https://www.archives.gov/research/catalog/lcdrg/appendix#list-non-preferred-and-preferred-terms


Resource Tabs at bottom of screen provide information on the following:

  • Guiding Principles
  • Style Guide
  • Titles and Captions
  • Terms (Preferred and Non-Preffered)
  • Geographic Place Names
  • Access Points

entrydata.input:
Guiding Principles for Reparative Description


The National Archives and Records Administration preserves and makes accessible the permanent records of the United States federal government. Archival records are the raw materials of history, and archivists work to make them publicly available can impact how events are remembered, whose stories are told, and which communities can find their experiences reflected in the national narrative. NARAs records capture millions of stories across hundreds of years and their contents continue to have a real, direct impact on peoples lives. NARAs records are the peoples records, and they should be equitably accessible.

NARA has a responsibility to repair inequities through our archival descriptive practices; this work is known in the larger archives profession as reparative description. We are committed to working with staff, communities, and peer institutions to assess and contextualize or update harmful descriptions and to establish standards and policies to guide staff in future description work. In this work, we will be guided by the following principles:

  1. TransparencyWe will increase transparency about the archival process and provide space and tools for user feedback. NARA pledges to find innovative ways to inform the public about the origin of our archival descriptions, including whether the language is original to the records creator or was written by NARA staff. Where feasible, we will maintain and make available old/outdated versions of descriptions. We will create simple, accessible ways for users to give feedback and we will publicly document our efforts on our website so that we can be held accountable and further maximize NARAs value to all of our users.

  2. LanguageWe recognize the vastness of NARAs holdings and descriptive metadata, and we commit to using innovative methods to find, assess, and repair descriptions with harmful terminology, valorizing terminology, and underdescription. We will seek to use individuals and communities preferred terminology, while recognizing that including outdated terminology in descriptions can provide researchers with important context and access points into historical records. We will work to alert users to such language and explain why archives workers have included it so we can truly make access happen for all.

  3. Institutional changeWe commit to a deliberative and thoughtful approach to archival description (including appraisal, processing, re-processing, digitization, and cataloging) that allows for community collaboration and cultural humility. We recognize the years of hard work put into achieving past description goals and providing basic access to our holdings, as well as the efforts of individual archives workers across NARA to implement reparative description. We commit to supporting archives staff and building our future through our people as we ask for their time and expertise to move forward.

  4. CollaborationOn an ongoing basis, we will seek input from marginalized people, colleagues within and outside of the archives field, and peer institutions about our descriptive practices. We will remain connected to our current users and work to build and rebuild relationships with marginalized communities by specifically acknowledging past wrongs, being transparent about our limitations, and following through on our commitments.

  5. Iterative/reflective processWe commit to making reparative description an ongoing, iterative process, not a one-time project. We welcome and will seek to implement public, stakeholder, and staff feedback, and we will continuously reflect upon our process to identify ways to improve.

  6. LeadershipWe acknowledge that people and organizations representing marginalized communities have led the archives profession in developing reparative description best practices, and we continue to learn from their work. We recognize their leadership and build on lessons learned as we work to fulfill NARAs role as a leader for government archives in implementing large-scale reparative description.


source: https://www.archives.gov/research/catalog/lcdrg/appendix#list-non-preferred-and-preferred-terms

entrydata.input:
General Guidance and Style Guide

Due to their complex history, the non-preferred terms cannot be uniformly replaced with other terms in NARAs archival descriptions or authority records. No terms will be completely removed from any description, in order to ensure transparency, access, and discovery; rather terms may be moved, contextualized, and/or deemphasized within a description.  Each instance must be reviewed for context and additional context should be provided when relevant and known.

We anticipate the preferred terms and the use of terms will continue to evolve over time. This guidance is a living document that we will continuously expand and update. Our community-based approach means that a terms usage may change or vary depending on the communities context and our analysis. 

NOTE: These changes apply to archival descriptions only, they do not apply to the content of the record.

input.name: Allow Student to Pass Regardless of Score

entrydata.input:
Titles and Original Captions

Titles may be changed to move potentially harmful terminology to another relevant field in the description (Other Title, General Note, or other notes) and use preferred terms and phrasing in the main Title field.

When reviewing a title with a non-preferred term or racial modifier, determine if it is better practice to remove all modifiers from the title or to replace it with the preferred term in the title. In many cases, it may be better practice to remove the term rather than use a preferred term, especially if the description elsewhere provides context in the subject access points or another note field.

Original titles may be captured in the Other Titles field. If a Title is changed, the information must be added to the General Note to explain the change, for transparency and discovery. Original captions for photographs with harmful terms should be moved to the Scope and Content Note according to the Lifecycle Data Requirements Guide (LCDRG) guidance.

Refer to the following LCDRG titles guidance.


  • Original Titles

  • Item Titles

  • Other Titles

Refer to the following LCDRG notes guidance

  • General Note

  • Scope and Content Note

    • Scope and Content Note: Photographs and other graphic materials

    • Scope and Content Note: Original captions for graphic materials

input.name: Allow Student to Pass Regardless of Score

entrydata.input:
Non-Preferred Terms in Quotes

Quotes require particular attention and contextualization, especially when they can perpetuate the potential harm caused by using the term. Context will be key in these instances. Much will depend on how and by whom the term was used and whether it was solely archivist-supplied. Direct quotations in which non-preferred terms appear generally should be retained but with care.  Be mindful that extensive quotes that veer towards overdescription should not be included simply because they seem interesting.  They should provide key context and enhance access and discovery. Alternatives to including direct quotations include paraphrasing (best for descriptions of non-digitized material) or transcription (best for digitized material).


List of Non-Preferred and Preferred Terms for Reparative Description

This list is intended to complement a style guide and is not intended to be an authority list. Please consult the subject authority file for access points.

Click the preferred term for guidance.

Non-preferred Term Preferred Term Date Added or Updated
Ghetto Inner city or Urban center 2023-06-27
Negress Black Woman 2023-06-27
Negro Black Person 2023-06-27
Nigger Black Person 2023-06-27
Slave Enslaved Person 2023-06-27
Slave owner, Slave holder, Slave master Enslaver 2023-06-27



Proposing and Adding Terms

The list of non-preferred and their associated preferred terms will expand over time. Additions to the list are reviewed and approved by the NARA Lifecycle Data Standards Board. Updates are added to the appendix.

If you find potentially harmful language in the Catalog description of historical records, we encourage you to email us at catalog@nara.gov and provide a link to an example.

input.name: Allow Student to Pass Regardless of Score

input.name: Do Not Display Check Answer Button

entrydata.input:
Geographic Place Names

Non-preferred terms in geographic place names are not uncommon. Often, the term was adopted informally and became the accepted place name. Formal names for place names that have not been changed officially should be retained in the authority records until the place name is formally changed. In instances where the place name has been officially changed or where the term is used only colloquially, the current or formal name should be adopted in the authority file as the preferred term and added as an access point.

input.name: Do Not Display Check Answer Button

entrydata.input:
Access Points

We encourage the use of subject and geographic place access points to increase access, provide context, and facilitate discovery.


  • Geographic Reference

  • Organizational Reference

  • Personal Reference

  • Topical Subject Reference

entrydata.input:
Kolya asks...

What Makes A Good Tag? 

NARA says...

Since adding tags enhances the National Archives Catalog search capabilities, we find that the best tags are the ones that add new information to a record that isnt already available. 

If you can find the word in the records title or scope and content note, add it as a tag - but dont stop there! You can further improve access to that record if you identify an object, person or action in a record that is not already in the description (NARA, 2023.)"

  Now Kolya will view several archival items from NARA that he wants to transcribe and tag (describe).  

  Help Kolya make decisions about how to implement new and emerging best practices for each unique scenario.  

Resource Tabs at bottom of screen not available on assessment pages.

entrydata.input:
Archive item 1 has a very offensive term. I doubt this is actually the volunteer soldier's name.

I'm uncomfortable typing the word "nigger" as part of the transcription or in the tag words.

I want to use best practices for reparative description. What should I do in this scenario?

When transcribing: keep the word "Nigger" as is.

When tagging: keep the word "Nigger" as the full name shown on record, but add a range of preferred terms to increase access points for discoverability.
entrydata.feedback:
CORRECT

"This archival description was reviewed and not revised as part of the NARA reparative description initiative on 7/20/2023. The term "nigger" used in the Title was determined to be the name of a person as cited by the War Department in the compiled military service record. Original archival records have not been altered."(NARA)


In accordance with NARA guidelines:

  • retain the word "Nigger" for the transcription 
  • retain the word "Nigger" for the description (in this case the tag words of the first and last name on record) 
  • add a range of preferred terms such as: Black, African American, Negro, Black soldier, etc. to increase access points and discoverability

NOTE: 

  • A researcher may specifically search for the term "nigger" for a variety of reasons.  Erasing this instance would erase the historical record that Bill's official military record lists this term as a surname.
  • A reasonable interpretation of this historic source could conclude that it is likely the subject of the record (Bill):
    •  did not have a surname
    • did not provide a surname 
OR
    • did provide a surname other than "Nigger" and that in any event, a military personnel opted to write in "Nigger" as a surname on this official record.  
Altering this would effectually erase that complex historical reality and would close a point of access for discoverability.


SEE: Rescource Tab "Terms_Pref_Non_Pref"

entrydata.input:
When transcribing: change the word "Nigger" to "African American".

When tagging: change the word "Nigger" to "Black".
entrydata.feedback:
PARTIALLY CORRECT

"This archival description was reviewed and not revised as part of the NARA reparative description initiative on 7/20/2023. The term "nigger" used in the Title was determined to be the name of a person as cited by the War Department in the compiled military service record. Original archival records have not been altered."(NARA)


In accordance with NARA guidelines:

  • retain the word "Nigger" for the transcription 
  • retain the word "Nigger" for the description (in this case the tag words of the first and last name on record) 
  • add a range of preferred terms such as: Black, African American, Negro, Black soldier, etc. to increase access points and discoverability

NOTE: 

  • A researcher may specifically search for the term "nigger" for a variety of reasons.  Erasing this instance would erase the historical record that Bill's official military record lists this term as a surname.
  • A reasonable interpretation of this historic source could conclude that it is likely the subject of the record (Bill):
  •  did not have a surname
  • did not provide a surname 

OR

  • did provide a surname other than "Nigger" and that in any event, a military personnel opted to write in "Nigger" as a surname on this official record.  

Altering this would effectually erase that complex historical reality and would close a point of access for discoverability.


SEE: Rescource Tab "Terms_Pref_Non_Pref"

entrydata.feedback:

  • did provide a surname other than "Nigger" and that in any event, a military personnel opted to write in "Nigger" as a surname on this official record.

Should I add tags that name the equipment?

entrydata.feedback:
CORRECT

Adding tags that enhance description makes them easier to find by key word searches.  

Archivists and volunteer archivists ought to be encouraged to tag material they encounter whenever possible.  Especially so, when they have specialized knowledge about the content of an archival item.

entrydata.input:
Upon closer inspection I see the n-word is used on the label of the photo. I'm not comfortable transcribing:

"jackladder "Nigger""

I need some advice.
Use reparative description practices to address this.
entrydata.feedback:
CORRECT

Erasing offensive terms from the records effectually erases the reality of (in this case) anti-Black racism.  Use restorative description practices to address harmful legacy descriptions.

NARA Guidelines:

"Due to their complex history, the non-preferred terms cannot be uniformly replaced with other terms in NARAs archival descriptions or authority records. No terms will be completely removed from any description, in order to ensure transparency, access, and discovery; rather terms may be moved, contextualized, and/or deemphasized within a description."  

"Each instance must be reviewed for context and additional context should be provided when relevant and known."

"NOTE: These changes apply to archival descriptions only, they do not apply to the content of the record."

entrydata.input: Write to NARA in the comment section stating that the label should have the term "Nigger" photoshopped and replaced with the word "Black" or "African American."
entrydata.feedback:
INCORRECT

Erasing offensive terms from the records effectually erases the reality of (in this case) anti-Black racism.  Use restorative description practices to address harmful legacy descriptions.

NARA Guidelines:

"Due to their complex history, the non-preferred terms cannot be uniformly replaced with other terms in NARAs archival descriptions or authority records. No terms will be completely removed from any description, in order to ensure transparency, access, and discovery; rather terms may be moved, contextualized, and/or deemphasized within a description."  

"Each instance must be reviewed for context and additional context should be provided when relevant and known."

"NOTE: These changes apply to archival descriptions only, they do not apply to the content of the record."

entrydata.input: Write to NARA in the comment section insisting that the label should be torn off of this photo.
entrydata.feedback:
INCORRECT

Erasing offensive terms from the records effectually erases the reality of (in this case) anti-Black racism.  Use restorative description practices to address harmful legacy descriptions.

NARA Guidelines:

"Due to their complex history, the non-preferred terms cannot be uniformly replaced with other terms in NARAs archival descriptions or authority records. No terms will be completely removed from any description, in order to ensure transparency, access, and discovery; rather terms may be moved, contextualized, and/or deemphasized within a description."  

"Each instance must be reviewed for context and additional context should be provided when relevant and known."

"NOTE: These changes apply to archival descriptions only, they do not apply to the content of the record."

entrydata.input:
I now know original records should not be altered. However, this archive item 2 is different from the military record scenario that listed the n-word as a surname in the original record.

Here, it looks like an archivist created this label and title using the n-word. That's a harmful legacy description, right?

What should I do?

When transcribing: move the term "Nigger" to the Other Title field and the Notes field to preserve the historical reality that this worker was labeled "Nigger" in past archival practice.

When tagging: omit the term "Nigger" and add contemporary 'preferred terms' including "Black" and "African American".
entrydata.feedback:
CORRECT

When transcribing: 

  • move the term "Nigger" to the Other Title field and the Notes field to preserve the historical reality that this worker was labeled "Nigger" in past archival practice.  

When tagging: 

  • omit the term "Nigger" and add contemporary 'preferred terms' including "Black" and "African American".

This renders it discoverable when searching for any of the aforementioned terms and ensures transparency about the original titled applied.  The term "Nigger" remains in the metadata, but not in the descriptive tag fields. 

See examples on next page.

entrydata.input:
When transcribing: replace the term "Nigger" with "Black" or "African American".

When tagging: omit the term "Nigger" and add contemporary 'preferred terms' including "Black" and "African American".
entrydata.feedback:
PARTIALLY CORRECT

When transcribing: 

  • move the term "Nigger" to the Other Title field and the Notes field to preserve the historical reality that this worker was labeled "Nigger" in past archival practice.  

When tagging: 

  • omit the term "Nigger" and add contemporary 'preferred terms' including "Black" and "African American".

This renders it discoverable when searching for any of the aforementioned terms and ensures transparency about the original titled applied.  The term "Nigger" remains in the metadata, but not in the descriptive tag fields. 

See examples on next page.

entrydata.input:
When transcribing: transcribe the original title as is. There is no need to do anything else.

When tagging: add the tag "Nigger" because it is in the original description.
entrydata.feedback:
INCORRECT

When transcribing: 

  • move the term "Nigger" to the Other Title field and the Notes field to preserve the historical reality that this worker was labeled "Nigger" in past archival practice.  

When tagging: 

  • omit the term "Nigger" and add contemporary 'preferred terms' including "Black" and "African American".

This renders it discoverable when searching for any of the aforementioned terms and ensures transparency about the original titled applied.  The term "Nigger" remains in the metadata, but not in the descriptive tag fields. 

See examples on next page.

ARCHIVE ITEM 2


SEE TRANSCRIPTION EXAMPLE & NOTES BELOW











The brackets indicate this is not part of the original description but were added by the transcriptionist.  When a volunteer 'citizen' archivist submits this for review, this method of reparative description will be brought to the attention of the reviewer.  In this way a note can be added to the Original Title or Other Notes fields. 


NOTE: 

The original description shows quotes on the word "Nigger".  This may indicate that in the past, an external archivist creating the label quoted a caption included with the photo from the records creator, the Department of Agriculture. Bureau of Forestry. 7/1/1901-7/1/1905.  Or this label may have been created by an internal archivist of the Department of Agriculture. 






source: NARA https://catalog.archives.gov/id/7102589


Review:

When transcribing: move the term "Nigger" to the Other Title field and the Notes field to preserve the historical reality that this worker was labeled "Nigger" in past archival practice.  

When tagging: omit the term "Nigger" and add contemporary 'preferred terms' including "Black" and "African American".

This renders it discoverable when searching for any of the aforementioned terms and ensures transparency about the original titled applied.  The term "Nigger" remains in the metadata, but not in the descriptive tag fields.

entrydata.input:
ARCHIVE ITEM 2


SEE DESCRIPTION (TAGS) EXAMPLE & NOTES BELOW


The tags shown above are some examples of contributing to the descriptive metadata using new and emerging best practices for reparative description.

  • Prior to applying restorative description practices shown below, this item was DISCOVERABLE using the search term "nigger".  
  • This item was NOT DISCOVERABLE using preferred terms such as "Black" or "African American" or even "worker".  
  • Without applying restorative description practices in this scenario... the presence and existence of Black workers in this context is either effectually erased or only represented in a dehumanizing way.














The brackets indicate this is not part of the original description but were added by the transcriptionist.  When a volunteer 'citizen' archivist submits this for review, this method of reparative description will be brought to the attention of the reviewer.  In this way a note can be added to the Original Title or Other Notes fields. 


NOTE: The original description shows quotes on the word "Nigger".  This may indicate that in the past, an external archivist creating the label quoted a caption included with the photo from the records creator, the Department of Agriculture. Bureau of Forestry. 7/1/1901-7/1/1905.  Or this label may have been created by an internal archivist of the Department of Agriculture. 

Here, restorative description intervenes to disrupt the continuation of anti-Black practices in traditional archiving while preserving the anti-Black reality of legacy descriptions. 






source: NARA https://catalog.archives.gov/id/7102589


Review:

When transcribing: move the term "Nigger" to the Other Title field and the Notes field to preserve the historical reality that this worker was labeled "Nigger" in past archival practice.  

When tagging: omit the term "Nigger" and add contemporary 'preferred terms' including "Black" and "African American".

This renders it discoverable when searching for any of the aforementioned terms and ensures transparency about the original titled applied.  The term "Nigger" remains in the metadata, but not in the descriptive tag fields.

entrydata.input:
Historical Context 

on the 

Term Squaw 



The S-word: Offensive or Not? 

(source: Indian Country Today News)


The word s-word certainly has had its share of history. In researching its meaning, s-word is either offensive or historically accurate in portraying a female Indian woman. According to which historian you speak to on any given day or which link you click in a Google search, there are several theories regarding the words origin. 

Most notably negative and perhaps the most feared definition of the word is that s-word translates to vagina.

source: Indian Country Today News https://ictnews.org/archive/the-word-squaw-offensive-or-not


Setting the Record Straight 

About Native Languages: 

Squaw

(source: Native Languages of the Americas)

Q: Why is the word "squaw" so offensive? Does it mean woman, wife, prostitute, or vagina? 

A: None of the above. "Squaw" is not an Indian word. 

It was probably invented by European colonists who could not pronounce a longer Indian word. 

In the Algonquian languages, which were spoken on the East Coast and were the first to be encountered by Europeans, many feminine nouns end in a suffix with a "kw" or "skw" sound. For example, in Meskwaki-Sauk, Thakiwakwe means a Sauk (Thakiwa) woman; in Micmac, muwineskw means a female bear (muwin); and in the Abenaki language, Cimakskwa means Mrs. Cimak. 

If the Europeans thought that meant "skwa" or "kwe" was the word for "woman," though, they made a mistake. It's just a suffix, like the English suffix "-ess" in "princess" or "seamstress." By itself, "squaw" means nothing in any living Algonquian language and no Indian speaker would ever use it to refer to herself, any more than an English woman would refer to herself as an "ess." (The words for 'woman' in the three languages listed above are ihkwewa, epit, and behanem, incidentally.) 

So were the Europeans originally trying to use their pidgin word "squaw" to refer to Indian women, wives, prostitutes, vaginas, or seamstresses for that matter? 

No one will ever know for sure, because there are Algonquian words ending in "-squa" or "-qua" referring to all these things. 

The likeliest thing is that those original colonists were not being insulting and were just trying and failing to use an Indian word for "woman." It is hard to learn another language and most of the early European immigrants had never done it before. However, since then the word has been used in a very racist and sexually abusive way, so it definitely has negative implications now. 

Like the "n-word," the word "squaw" should be retired from public use. It is also not an Indian word and no Indians ever use it among themselves.

source: Native Languages of the Americas https://www.native-languages.org/iaq5.htm

input.name: Allow Student to Pass Regardless of Score

input.items: Challenger;Crossword;FIB;FlashCards;Form;Gate;IFrame;Interview;Journal;Long Answer;Multiple Choice Question;Multiple Select Question;Organizer;Report;Short Answer;SimpleSim;Text;Video;Wall;

input.name: Do Not Display Check Answer Button

entrydata.input: I recall reading that the word "squaw" for Indigenous North Americans is similar to the n-word for Black people. I also remember I shouldn't erase points of access for discoverability. I'm not sure. Should I change this word in the transcription and description (tag words) or not?

When transcribing: change the title word "Squaw" to "Hopi man having hair dressed" but be sure to note in the Other Titles and General Notes fields.

When tagging (describing): the document: omit the legacy description word "Squaw" and use a variety of tag words including "Hopi woman".
entrydata.feedback:
CORRECT

When transcribing, change the title words "Hopi person having hair dressed" but the original title ought to be noted in the Other Titles and General Notes fields to provide record of change, transparency and discoverability.

When tagging (describing) the document: omit the legacy description words "his squaw"; include a multitude of descriptors for increased points of access/ discoverability, i.e,. Hopi, Hopi woman, Hopi man, Hopituh- Shi- nu-mu, Pueblo, Uto-Aztecan, Indigenous, Indigenous North American, Native American, American Indian, North American Indian

 

note:

  • In a search for the word "squaw" this item is still discoverable.  By moving it to the Other Titles, transparency is provided about the historical realities in archival practices and society writ large. 
  • When changing archival descriptors from "non-preferred" terms to "preferred" terms, there is not always a singular preferred term.  I.e., Black or African-American, Native American, American Indian, Indigenous North American, Aboriginal, First Nations, are all terms that some but not all people within the racialized categories approve of.  
Whenever and wherever possible, refer to people as they wish to be referred to.  Because people are not monolithic, neither is agreement on labels and racialized categorical terms. 

  • In many Indigenous North American cultures, the concept of "Two Spirit" exists as an option to the binary gendering of just "man" or "woman".  It is also impossible to know if the person in the photo is "his [woman]" as listed in the legacy description. 

See: example on next page

See: Resource Tab "Titles_Captions"

entrydata.input:
When transcribing: change the title word "Squaw" to "Indigenous Native North American".

When tagging (describing): change the word "Squaw" to "Indigenous Native North American".
entrydata.feedback:
PARTIALLY CORRECT

When transcribing, change the title words "Hopi person having hair dressed" but the original title ought to be noted in the Other Titles and General Notes fields to provide record of change, transparency and discoverability.

When tagging (describing) the document: omit the legacy description words "his squaw"; include a multitude of descriptors for increased points of access/ discoverability, i.e,. Hopi, Hopi woman, Hopi man, Hopituh- Shi- nu-mu, Pueblo, Uto-Aztecan, Indigenous, Indigenous North American, Native American, American Indian, North American Indian

 

note:

  • In a search for the word "squaw" this item is still discoverable.  By moving it to the Other Titles, transparency is provided about the historical realities in archival practices and society writ large. 
  • When changing archival descriptors from "non-preferred" terms to "preferred" terms, there is not always a singular preferred term.  I.e., Black or African-American, Native American, American Indian, Indigenous North American, Aboriginal, First Nations, are all terms that some but not all people within the racialized categories approve of.  
Whenever and wherever possible, refer to people as they wish to be referred to.  Because people are not monolithic, neither is agreement on labels and racialized categorical terms. 

  • In many Indigenous North American cultures, the concept of "Two Spirit" exists as an option to the binary gendering of just "man" or "woman".  It is also impossible to know if the person in the photo is "his [woman]" as listed in the legacy description. 

See: example on next page

See: Resource Tab "Titles_Captions"

entrydata.input:
When transcribing: change the title word "Squaw" to "Indian".

When tagging (describing): change the word "Squaw" to "Indigenous Native North American".
entrydata.feedback:
INCORRECT

When transcribing, change the title words "Hopi person having hair dressed" but the original title ought to be noted in the Other Titles and General Notes fields to provide record of change, transparency and discoverability.

When tagging (describing) the document: omit the legacy description words "his squaw"; include a multitude of descriptors for increased points of access/ discoverability, i.e,. Hopi, Hopi woman, Hopi man, Hopituh- Shi- nu-mu, Pueblo, Uto-Aztecan, Indigenous, Indigenous North American, Native American, American Indian, North American Indian

 

note:

  • In a search for the word "squaw" this item is still discoverable.  By moving it to the Other Titles, transparency is provided about the historical realities in archival practices and society writ large. 
  • When changing archival descriptors from "non-preferred" terms to "preferred" terms, there is not always a singular preferred term.  I.e., Black or African-American, Native American, American Indian, Indigenous North American, Aboriginal, First Nations, are all terms that some but not all people within the racialized categories approve of.  
Whenever and wherever possible, refer to people as they wish to be referred to.  Because people are not monolithic, neither is agreement on labels and racialized categorical terms. 

  • In many Indigenous North American cultures, the concept of "Two Spirit" exists as an option to the binary gendering of just "man" or "woman".  It is also impossible to know if the person in the photo is "his [woman]" as listed in the legacy description. 

See: example on next page

See: Resource Tab "Titles_Captions"

entrydata.input:
ARCHIVE ITEM 3


SEE TRANSCRIPTION EXAMPLE BELOW


The use of brackets in sample transcription above is to call attention to the reviewers at NARA to move the "by his squaw" part of the title as noted when they review this transcription for approval.



SEE DESCRIPTION (TAGS) EXAMPLE BELOW























source: NARA (US National Archives and Records Administration) https://catalog.archives.gov/id/530948?objectPage=2


Review:

When transcribing, change the title words "Hopi person having hair dressed" but the original title ought to be noted in the Other Titles and General Notes fields to provide record of change, transparency and discoverability.

When tagging (describing) the document: omit the legacy description words "his squaw"; include a multitude of descriptors for increased points of access/ discoverability, i.e,. Hopi, Hopi woman, Hopi man, Hopituh- Shi- nu-mu, Pueblo, Uto-Aztecan, Indigenous, Indigenous North American, Native American, American Indian, North American Indian

 

note:

  • In a search for the word "squaw" this item is still discoverable.  By moving it to the Other Titles, transparency is provided about the historical realities in archival practices and society writ large. 
  • When changing archival descriptors from "non-preferred" terms to "preferred" terms, there is not always a singular preferred term.  I.e., Black or African-American, Native American, American Indian, Indigenous North American, Aboriginal, First Nations, are all terms that some but not all people within the racialized categories approve of.  
Whenever and wherever possible, refer to people as they wish to be referred to.  Because people are not monolithic, neither is agreement on labels and racialized categorical terms. 

  • In many Indigenous North American cultures, the concept of "Two Spirit" exists as an option to the binary gendering of just "man" or "woman".  It is also impossible to know if the person in the photo is "his [woman]" as listed in the legacy description. 

See: Resource Tab "Titles_Captions"

entrydata.input:
Each scenario of reparative description depends on context.  

The NARA guidelines offer the basics of best practices and a pathway that leads to reparative description in archives. 

 

Reparative description is an iterative process.

Each scenario of reparative description depends on context. The NARA guidelines offer the basics of best practices and a pathway that leads to reparative description in archives. Do you want to conclude the learning session or go over the scenarios with Kolya again for a chance to improve your score?
I feel confident in knowledge of the NARA guidelines for reparative description. I WANT TO CONCLUDE MY SESSION.
I feel confident in knowledge of the NARA guidelines for reparative description but I WANT TO GO OVER THE MATERIAL WITH KOLYA AGAIN AND TRY TO IMPROVE MY SCORE.
I am not yet confident I understand the NARA guidelines for reparative description. I WANT TO GO OVER THE MATERIAL WITH KOLYA AGAIN AND TRY TO IMPROVE MY SCORE.

Optional Resources

Full video on "Reparative Description" by Amhurst Freedom Museum with guest Melissa Nelson:

        •  Reparative Description: Confronting Anti-Blackness in Archives


Further learning resource list provided by Melissa J. Nelson:


Archives for Black Lives in Philadelphia Anti-Racist Description Working Group:

      • link

Charlotte G. Lellman. (2020, September 3). Guidelines for Inclusive and Conscientious Description. Harvard Wiki. 

      • link

Labors of Love: Proposing Participatory Archival and Para-Archival Practices. 

      • link

Kristen Wright. (2022). Archival interventions and the language we use. 

      • link

From Human Rights to Feminist Ethics: Radical Empathy in the Archives. Archivaria, 81, 2343. 

      • link

P. Gabrielle Foreman, et al. Writing about Slavery/Teaching About Slavery: This Might Help. 

      • link

Jessica Tai. (2020). Cultural Humility as a Framework for Anti-Oppressive Archival Description. Journal of Critical Library and Information Studies, 3, 123.

      • link

Melissa J. Nelson. (2020, March 18). Archiving Hate: Racist Materials in Archives. 

      • link

Melissa J. Nelson (Host). (2022). Archives & Things Podcast. https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast... 

Sam Winn. (2017, April 24). The Hubris of Neutrality in Archives. On Archivy.
